resources.string: This is your health. To heal, tap your health.
This is your armor. To equip armor, tap your armor.
This is your weapon damage. To equip a weapon, tap your weapon damage. Next to your weapon damage there is an attack counter.
Tap this button when you attack and your attack counter will go down.
Use the number scroller to indicate how much damage you want to take, then tap "Take Damage". If you want damage to ignore your armor, toggle the "direct" switch.
This is an undo button. It will undo the last damage calculation.
Tap here if you want to run through help again.

string-array.name: HowToDescripStrings
string-array.item:
Shuffle role cards and distribute one to each player. You can never show your role card to another player. Each player begins with 1000 Health Points (HP) 


For 4 Players: Assassin, Queen, King, and Jack 
 For 5 Players: 2 Assassins. Queen, King, and Jack 
 For 6 Players: 3 Assassins. Queen, King, and Jack 


Every Player begins with 5 cards and no one can attack with their weapon on their first turn

Draw one card at the start of each turn. A player can choose to play an ability card, replace any weapons and armors, donate cards to any other player, or declare an attack. Attacking is done last in a turn. No one can attack on their first turn. At the end of a player’s turn, they can be holding no more than 7 cards. Any extra cards must be donated or discarded.

Only one weapon and one armor may be equipped at a time. A player’s weapon and armor can be replaced at the end of any player’s turn, after they attack, or on their own turn. If a weapon or armor is already equipped but the player wants to equip a new one, the player may discard the weapon or armor and play another one from their hand. A weapon can only be used to attack 3 times. If the attack is stopped, it does not count as an attack for the weapon. Tier 1, 2, and 3 weapons deal 100, 200, and 300 damage respectively. Armor takes damage from a weapon instead of it being taken from a player’s HP. Tier 1, 2, and 3 armors have 100, 200, and 300 health. An armor’s health is different from a player’s HP. When an armor loses all of its health, the armor is destroyed and the remaining damage is dealt to the player’s HP. For example, if a tier 3 armor gets hit by a tier 1 weapon, then that armor takes the 100 damage and now has 200 health left to protect the player. If a tier 3 weapon hits a tier 1 armor, the armor is destroyed and the player takes 200 damage to their HP. If a weapon attacks a player with equal tiers, then the armor is destroyed and no damage is taken.
Ability cards can only be played on the player’s turn. A player can only play one ability card per turn unless specified otherwise.
Effect cards can be played on any turn, usually when a person is being attacked or targeted.

Purple cards are enchantments on weapons and armors. They can only be played on the player’s turn. Multiple can be played in one turn and multiple can be applied to the same weapon or armor. The enchantment card is discarded when the weapon or armor is destroyed. If a card’s possession changes, the enchantments move with it.

The “field” encompasses all the cards on the table. There is a draw pile, a discard pile, and each player’s own section of the field. In a player’s section, they should have their role card face down and their HP visible if asked for. If a card is played that targets a player, it is placed on their side of the field. For example, if Player A plays Bound on Player B, it is kept on Player B’s field until the effect is over.

When a player dies, they discard their hand and cannot disclose any information on their roles or any other players’. The dead player must look at every person’s role and determine if the game is over or if they must continue playing. The player who does the killing gains 200 HP (cannot go above 1000 HP) and draws 2 cards. If multiple players’ cards are responsible for the death, then no players collect the reward.

Assassin: The assassins win by killing the King, Queen, and Jack.

 King: The King wins by surviving with the Queen. If the Queen dies, the King cannot win, but may still be the last player to survive.

 Queen: The Queen wins by surviving with the King or the Jack (only if the King is dead).

 Jack: The Jack wins by surviving with the Queen, but must kill the King. If the Queen dies, the Jack cannot win, but may be the last player to survive.

 The game ends when there is only one person alive, only Assassins alive, or when the Queen survives with the King or Jack.
